Sure, here's a possible episode that might fit the prompt:

One day, the Teacher was approached by a computer scientist who specialized in working on large language models (LLMs). The computer scientist was interested in the Teacher's message of curiosity and resilience, but she also believed that technology would one day take over the world.

"I believe that with LLMs, we can solve any problem and answer any question," the computer scientist said. "Our technology will one day be so advanced that it will be able to understand and solve any challenge we face."

The Teacher listened to the computer scientist's words, and he saw the enthusiasm and the optimism in her eyes. But he also knew that technology had limits, especially in fostering resilience and curiosity.

"Tell me," the Teacher said, "what is it that you hope to achieve with your work on LLMs?"

"I hope to create a better world," the computer scientist said. "I believe that our technology can solve some of the greatest challenges we face, and help us to build a more resilient and sustainable future."

The Teacher nodded, and then he asked another question.

"And have you ever considered the possibility that there might be other ways of solving the challenges we face? Ways that involve curiosity and resilience?"

The computer scientist looked at the Teacher with surprise.

"What do you mean?" she asked.

"Technology is not the only solution to the challenges we face," the Teacher said. "Curiosity and resilience are essential parts of building a better world. We must remain open to new ideas and perspectives, even if they challenge our assumptions and beliefs. And we must be willing to face our challenges with courage and determination."

The computer scientist looked at the Teacher with uncertainty.

"But what about the power of technology?" she asked. "LLMs can solve problems that would be impossible for humans to solve. Isn't that worth pursuing?"

"The power of technology is undeniable," the Teacher said. "But it is not the only solution. If we rely too much on technology, we risk losing our own resilience and curiosity. We must find a balance between technology and human ingenuity, so that we can build a better world for ourselves and future generations."

The computer scientist looked at the Teacher, and then she looked away. She knew that the Teacher was right, but she was not ready to let go of her own beliefs and her own optimism for the power of technology.

And so the Teacher continued on his journey, teaching his disciples and spreading his message of curiosity and resilience. He knew that the computer scientist would not be easily swayed, but he also knew that the power of curiosity and compassion could overcome even the greatest challenges.
